body: Hi, thanks again for reaching out! Do you have a particular algorithm in mind that you want to extend to handle unequal-length series?

issue.title: Roadmap

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:

body:
As @mloning says, it would be good if you could state which estimators/methods this affects and which you are going to work on, as well as how your fix would look like (as algorithm or formula).

Would you mind explaining?

An important discussion point would be what type your fix is:
(a) a transformer which applies to all methods that don´t work for unequally spaced or length series? 
(b) a custom modificiation of a specific method, e.g., time series forest?
(c) a bugfix that is specific to one method?

Because in case (b) you would become the "owner" of the modified method - it might be improved, but it is a "new" one (since it might not be the one described in the original paper and is based on your additional idea). In (c) the original maintainer remains the owner, since it is just an error fix. In (a) you would write a transformer.

(@mloning , this is how it would be according to the maintenance document, right?)

On this it also depends where your code would go.

Agree.

First I looked at ShapeletTransformClassifier, which lead me into the ShapeletTransform class. Where I found that a few changes can make it work with unequal sizes. 
Changes at ShapeletTransform are:
1) another way of feeding ShapeletTransform.zscore. Used "np.array([dim[cand_start_pos: cand_start_pos + cand_len] for dim in X[series_id]])" instead of "X[series_id][:,cand_start_pos: cand_start_pos + cand_len]". An the same trick with other ShapeletTransform.zscore calls.
This fixes slicing time series, if they are of different sizes, X has [samples_n, features_n] shape, where X[0, 0] will be time series with other than X[1, 0] or X[0, 1] sizes. Our matrix is no longer fully rectanglar.
2) tried another condition in the comparison cycle with respect for shorter series.

If I understood @fkiraly  right, this is for (a).

Now I've noticed that there is a restriction on equality of series sizes among series in a sample, but I haven't run into this because my series are 1-dimensional.

But also, I'm interested in adapting TimeSeriesForestClassifier.

I see - so it`s either a bugfix, or a proper extension to a transformer (not a classifier). I´m not sure which it is, but according to the register
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/dev/ESTIMATOR_OVERVIEW.md
the owner of shapelet transform is @jasonlines .

@jasonlines , would the proposed change be a genuine extension (new method), or a fix, in your opinion?

Probably a fix?

Regarding time series forest, I believe there are two versions of it: one which is a composite, and one which is an atom. 

I assume you propose to do some transformation at the start?

@mloning , for the composite, which parts would have to get updated to be compatible with unequal length series?

We should probably put the composite (as code) in the table too.

rename.from: errors while fiting on datasets of unequal sized time series
rename.to: extending existing estimators to samples of unequal length time series

body:
For time series forest, the random interval segmentation would have to be adapted. 
* For the modular version, this happens in the [RandomIntervalSegmenter](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/4dabe1afee0ad180f31c5f585f904f515ab4d0b1/sktime/transformers/segment.py#L113). 
* For the hard-coded one, it happens in the [fit](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/4dabe1afee0ad180f31c5f585f904f515ab4d0b1/sktime/classifiers/interval_based/tsf.py#L84) and transform method. @TonyBagnall any thoughts on changing the hard-coded version, I know it reproduces the bake-off, so perhaps we want to leave it untouched?

hi, sorry for being late to this. Jason implemented the ShapeletTransform, so he will respond. But logically, it should be pretty easy to generalise for unequal length, and it would be a reall good thing to do. We have around 20 or so problems like this, and it has been high on my wish list for some time.

so I think the logic of ST is this
randomly generate a shapelet candidate.
   1. Pick a random series
   2. Pick a random start point
   3. pick a random length
this should all work with unequal length series, hopefully already

once you have selected a random candidate, you need to evaluate it. This involves 
1. running the candidate over every other season to find the distance to the nearest neighbour. 
2. storing the min distances for all series
3. Assess how well these distances split the data
(2) and (3) remain the same. Step 1 is the same, except for an edge case: what if the candidate is longer than the series being evaluated? Other two need no change. One way to handle the edge case is to simply reverse it: Given candidate S and series X, 
    if(|S|<|X|)
          minDist(S,X)
   else
          minDist(X,S) 
I havent thought about this much, but it seems a reasonable first approach. Not their are data characteristics that would influence the efficacy of this approach i.e. why are are series unequal length? Is it different sampling rates, different experimental stop time, start and stop time etc
@DmitriyValetov , while waiting for @jasonlines , it probably makes most sense to work towards a PR that modifies the existing estimators - @mloning , what do you think?
